lg.l: kaṇṭēttuñ cevvēḷeṉ ṟicaipōkkik kātalāṟkoṇṭēttuṅ kiḻamaiyāṉ kōvalaṉeṉ pāṉmaṉṉō
We praise the moon, we praise the moon,
Because of its care [towards] this beautiful world,
[It] Resembling the cool, white parasol of [the king] Ceṉṉi
With a garland upon which [flowers with] pollen open.
We praise the sun, we praise the sun,
Because of its rightward cruise around the golden peaks of mount Mēṟu,
Like the discus of the Lord of the land of Kāvēri.
We praise the great raincloud, we praise the great raincloud,
Because of his pouring forth, standing above
To the world with the fearful fence of water (= the ocean).
We praise beautiful Pukār, We praise beautiful Pukār,
Because of its [superior] conduct, having spread loftily
Along with His clan, for the sake of the world with a fence of swelling waters.
Even if it Potiyil mountain, even if it is the Himalaya,
Even if it is indeed Pukār of an excellence that severs mundaneness,
In which ancient clans that do not know to leave the place [of Pukār] are abundant,
Apart from the saying that it [Pukār] is permanent [fn. is shortened nilaiiyatu]
Those who perceive completely the lessons that were completed with truth,
Are those who do not speak of [its] limitations. [grammar: muṟṟeccam]
With the long city of snakes and the land of snakes along with it,
And the city of Pukār that is permanent in its prosperous, long fame - in that [city]
Was she who was no less than twelve years [of age],
Who was she who resembled a golden, sky-high [=superior] creeper -
A branch [= family member/girl] of the clan of the great sea-merchant
With generous hands that resemble the spacious skies;
Was she who was Tiru that filled [= sat inside] the [lotus] flower;
Saying, 'the quality of the North Star devoid of evil,
That is always a form that possesses beauty,
The lady-love [= bride] of great, good quallities that were resplendent
Was indeed she who was called ‘Kaṇṇaki’, which was permanent [=everlasting] as a name.
Was he who was called Mācāttuvāṉ,
[He] having filled the growing treasury wealth for others’ sake
[He] having been raised [in stature] along with singularly unique clans
That placed as [their] head [= leader] the great son [=king/prince]
That ruled entirely the big lands [=world];
The son of [this] hero of two [kinds of] wealth
Was he who was no less than sixteen years [of age];
He of the fame that reduced [the fame of] the earth;
Moon-faced ladies praising him in groups, with speech that reduced [i.e. put to shame] music,
Seeing [him], initiating music that went, ‘[He is] Cevvēḷ who is praised!’,
He who was right to be praised, having been possessed by love,
Both of the two great [sets of] parents we delighted to see them
[In their] adornments of [marital] union, on one great day.
They who rejoiced thus, having seated ladies with beautiful jewels
Upon the neck of an elephant,
Granted [notice of] the union to the great city.
muracu drums resounded; muruṭu drums reverbrated;
The conch and the white parasol according to the rising of the king.
Inside the inner town, auspicious decorations rose [i.e.abounded].
Inside [an enclosure with] diamond and sapphire pillars from whose roof hung garlands,
Under a flower arbour with pearls, with a dark blue canopy [i.e. the sky],
As the moon that roams the sky approached the Cakaṭu constellation,
What an observance [it was] for those who witnessed Kōvalaṉ performing the rightward [circumambulation] of the fire
To her who was befitting of the singular star that was the possessor of the skies
As the great, ancient brahmin showed [them] the way of the Vedas.
Fragrant women, flower-like women, those with shining bodies,
Those who talk, those who sing, those with hesistant [i.e. shy] glances,
Those with [sandal] paste, those with incense, those with/like swaying garlands,
Those with eminent, young breasts, those with pounded [cosmetic] powders,
Those with lamps, those with jewels, those in rows with pots with young shoots
Those resembling golden, fragrant creepers, with tresses that bloomed with the buds [in their hair],
Praising, saying, ’not separating from the lover, [their] hands that are intertwined not slipping away,
They raised her who resembled Arunati [star] in [this] pretty world
The bright tiger [of the Cēras] that was created on the Himalaya over here,
Being one that is in proximity to the golden peak [Mēru] over there,
Cempiyaṉ with an angry spear, abundant in fighting,
Will always whirl the unique, singular discus [i.e., the wheel of Dharma].
